pullRequest.body:
Define elaborators (but no delaborators) to elaborate the following notations to a `Finset`:

In `Data.Finset.Basic`,
* `{x âˆˆ s | p x}`

In `Data.Fintype.Basic`,
* `{x | p x}`
* `{x : Î± | p x}`
* `{x âˆ‰ s | p x}`
* `{x â‰  a | p x}`

In `Order.Interval.Finset.Basic`,
* `{x â‰¤ a | p x}`
* `{x â‰¥ a | p x}`
* `{x < a | p x}`
* `{x > a | p x}`

The general heuristic for deciding whether to elaborate a given notation as a `Set` or `Finset` is:
* Check whether the expected type is `Finset ?Î±`.
  * If it is, elaborate as a `Finset`.
  * If it isn't, check whether the expected type of `s` in the notation is  `Finset ?Î±`.
    * If it is, elaborate as a `Finset`.
    * If it isn't or there is no `s` in the notation, elaborate as a `Set`.

There is currently a gotcha that elaboration to `Set` is highly preferred because we can't postpone metavariable and override the set elaborator without breaking many existing uses of set builder notation. See [Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/113488-general/topic/.7Bx.20.E2.88.88.20s.20.7C.20p.20x.7D.20notation.20for.20finset).

---

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they

nodes.body: The new notations here intersect a lot with the notations introduced by #6795, so I'm thinking I should be creating a new syntax category `setBinder` instead of reusing the existing `binderPred`.

### PR summary [985d7de269](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/11582/commits/985d7de2693b83e369a6d480bce48639659d61ba)

| --- | --- | --- | --- |

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Init.Set`|1|

</details>

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ elabFinsetBuilderIxx`
`+ elabFinsetBuilderSep`
`+ elabFinsetBuilderSetOf`
`+ elabSetBuilder`
`+ knownToBeFinsetNotSet`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

```
</details>

</details>

> The new notations here intersect a lot with the notations introduced by #6795, so I'm thinking I should be creating a new syntax category `setBinder` instead of reusing the existing `binderPred`.

Given that this is completely orthogonal to the current PR, I will do that in a later PR.

Could we please have a test file containing the full list from the PR description? 

(It would be good also to have a module doc in that test file explaining where each is implemented.)
maintainer merge

Thanks!

bors r+

Build failed (retrying...):
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10411715313/job/28836163629)
This PR was included in a batch that was canceled, it will be automatically retried

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10412943710/job/28839548145)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10412943710/job/28839547998)
Thanks for the PR! Generally looks clean to me. Here are some remaining comments

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion theorem Pairwise.set_pairwise (hl : Pairwise R l) (hr : Symmetric R) : ```

Based on the code, shouldn't this be:
```suggestion
/-- Return `true` if `expectedType?` is `some (Finset ?Î±)`, throws `throwUnsupportedSyntax` if it is
`some (Set ?Î±)`, and returns `false` otherwise. -/
```
This code is very repetitive, especially the comments. Do you think you can factor out a function (that holds all these comments), and then makes the `elabTerm` a straightforward application?

How much should I factor out? All elaborators check `expectedType?`, but the elaborators for `{x \in s | p x}` and `{x \nin s | p x}` also check the type of `s`.

Further, I would think I should leave the comments in the end code because this is the one people will try modifying in the future.

In short, I don't think I can factor much more than the two lines `unless ... throwUnsupportedSyntax`.
Actually I could just move the comment to `knownToBeFinsetNotSet` and it all makes sense

```suggestion
  type is `Finset ?Î²`.
```
\a?
That's not a typo. `?Î²` is a metavariable that (eventually) gets unified to `Î±`.
Yes, I am adding a TODO for a proper delaborator in this PR

This comment was not about the `delaborator`, but the `elaborator`: I was merely asking if this means that the user has to be very careful where they put the coersions.

But I think that's already now the case with `Set` vs `Finset`, and I think that's fine
EDIT: (looking at the test file again, I see you did a good job listing all introduced notations!), could you maybe add another test about the described behaviour in regard to `Set` vs. `Finset`.

Sorry, can you be more precise? Do you want something like
```
example (s : Set Î±) : {x âˆˆ s | p x} = {x | x âˆˆ s âˆ§ p x} := rfl
```
?
I added a suggestion below with the tests I think could be useful. I think the PR is ready to be merged after you had a time to look at that :)
What's the reason for moving this up and outside of the `BooleanAlgebra` section?
I need `sá¶œ` to make sense to write the elaborator and I want to be able to use the elaborator in the rest of the section, so I had to cut the section in half with the elaborator in the middle,
Ah yes, that makes sense. Didn't realise that `sá¶œ` requires the `BooleanAlgebra` instance.

```suggestion
* `{x : Î² | p x}` is elaborated as `Finset.filter (fun x : Î² â†¦ p x) Finset.univ` if the expected
  type is `Finset ?Î±`.
```

I understand Kim's confusion. Maybe writing it this way around would empathise more that it is deliberate the way it's written?

Or just `Î±` and `?Î±` and brush over the fact that they aren't unified yet?
I've chosen the brushing ðŸ’‡

```suggestion
-- If the type of `s` (or the entire expression) is `Finset ?Î±`, elaborate as `Finset`;
-- otherwise as `Set`
example (s : Finset Î±) : {x âˆˆ s | p x} = s.filter p := rfl
example (s : Finset Î±) : ({x âˆˆ s | p x} : Set Î±) = setOf fun x => x âˆˆ s âˆ§ p x := rfl
example (s : Finset Î±) : {x âˆˆ (s : Set Î±) | p x} = setOf fun x => x âˆˆ s âˆ§ p x := rfl

-- elaborate as `Set` if no expected type present
example : {x | p x} = setOf p := rfl
example : {x : Î± | p x} = setOf p := rfl

variable [DecidableEq Î±]

example (s : Finset Î±) : {x âˆ‰ s | p x} = sá¶œ.filter p := rfl
example (a : Î±) : ({x â‰  a | p x} : Finset Î±) = ({a}á¶œ : Finset Î±).filter p := rfl

-- elaborate as `Set` if the `s` or the expected type is not `Finset ?Î±`
example (s : Set Î±) : {x âˆ‰ s | p x} = setOf fun x => x âˆ‰ s âˆ§ p x := rfl
example (a : Î±) : {x â‰  a | p x} = setOf fun x => x â‰  a âˆ§ p x := rfl

end Fintype

/-! ## `Order.Interval.Finset.Basic` -/

section LocallyFiniteOrderBot
variable [Preorder Î±] [LocallyFiniteOrderBot Î±]

example (a : Î±) : ({x â‰¤ a | p x} : Finset Î±) = (Iic a).filter p := rfl
example (a : Î±) : ({x < a | p x} : Finset Î±) = (Iio a).filter p := rfl

-- elaborate as `Set` if the expected type is not `Finset ?Î±`
example (a : Î±) : {x â‰¤ a | p x} = setOf fun x => x â‰¤ a âˆ§ p x := rfl
example (a : Î±) : {x < a | p x} = setOf fun x => x < a âˆ§ p x := rfl

end LocallyFiniteOrderBot

section LocallyFiniteOrderTop
variable [Preorder Î±] [LocallyFiniteOrderTop Î±]

example (a : Î±) : ({x â‰¥ a | p x} : Finset Î±) = (Ici a).filter p := rfl
example (a : Î±) : ({x > a | p x} : Finset Î±) = (Ioi a).filter p := rfl

-- elaborate as `Set` if the expected type is not `Finset ?Î±`
example (a : Î±) : {x â‰¥ a | p x} = setOf fun x => x â‰¥ a âˆ§ p x := rfl
example (a : Î±) : {x > a | p x} = setOf fun x => x > a âˆ§ p x := rfl

end LocallyFiniteOrderTop

```
It's too bad that this `elabTerm s none` is wasted work. Maybe in a followup it could be saved and then inserted into the Syntax on line 2201 using `exprToSyntax`.
Yes, that makes sense

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: Finset builder notation
